Workshop:

Topics in Random Media

Santiago, Chile, July 24 & 25, 2014.

Organizers:

Millenium Nucleus - Stochastic Models of Complex and Disordered Systems

Department of Mathematics - PUC Chile

Department of Mathematical Engineering - University of Chile

Minicourses:

Alexander Fribergh (Toulouse)

Christophe Sabot (Lyon)

Lorenzo Zambotti (Paris)

About the Workshop

The workhop Topics in Random Media will be held in Santiago, Chile on Thursday and Friday before the SPA of Buenos Aires. It will feature minicourses on RWRE by A. Fribergh and Ch. Sabot, and a minicourse on Regularity Structures by L. Zambotti. In addition, there will be a small number of talks.

Please, refer to the schedule on the right for titles and abstracts.

Registration and Funding

Registration is free but mandatory. Please, contact the organizers to let us know you intend to participate. We also have funding for several graduate students from Southamerica. Please, submit any request before June 10th.

Practical Information

The talk will be held at the department of mathematics of PUC-Chile. Have a look at the following link for information on housing and how to get here.

For any inquiry, please, contact the organizers.

Contact topicsrandommedia@gmail.com

Practical Information

The workshop will be held at Campus San Joaquín. The campus is situated on the line 5 of the 'metro'. If you come from the north, take line 5 in the direction 'Vicente Valdés'. Be aware that, during rush hour, trains do not stop at every station.

More information to be posted soon.

Alex Fribergh

Biased random walk on supercritical percolation clusters

We will present results on biased random walks on supercritical percolation clusters. This a natural model for observing trapping phenomena and anomalous long-term behaviors. We will explain why this model exhibits a phase transition from positive speed to zero speed as the bias increases. Furthermore, we shall discuss a subtle difficulty appearing when trying to rescale such a process to obtain scaling limits. One of our goals will be to explain the key tools used to analyze random walks in random environments that are directionally transient. This talk will be based on past and ongoing work of Alexander Fribergh and Alan Hammond.

Christophe Sabot

Edge Reinforced Random Walk, Vertex Reinforced Jump Process and related topics

The Edge Reinforced Random Walk (ERRW) and the Vertex Reinforced Jump Process (VRJP) are self-interacting random processes that have a tendency to come back to their past trajectory. In these lectures I will explain how these processes are related with a supersymetric sigma-field introduced by Zirnbauer and investigated by Disertori, Spencer, Zirnbauer. These processes exhibit a transition between recurrence and transience in dimension d>=3, I will explain the main ideas of the localization/delocalization arguments. Finally, I will explain some new relations with isomorphism theorems for classical Markov Jump Processes. Based on joint works with Tarrès and Disertori, Tarrès.

Lorenzo Zambotti

Renormalization of random distributions and SPDEs

We give an overview of recent results and ongoing work on the renormalization of stochastic partial differential equations containing non-linear functions of random distributions in the context of Martin Hairer's theory of regularity structures. We will focus on the construction of the renormalized products of random distributions and the associated combinatorial description in terms of Feynman diagrams.

Vincent Tassion

Title and abstract TBA. Bla

Julien Sohier

Levy multiplicative chaos and star scale invariant random measures

We consider the continuous analog of the celebrated Mandelbrot star equation with infinitely divisible weights. Mandel- brot introduced this equation to characterize the law of multiplicative cascades. We show existence and uniqueness of measures satisfying the aforementioned continuous equation. We obtain an explicit char- acterization of the structure of these measures, which reflects the constraints imposed by the continuous setting. In particular, we show that the continuous equation enjoys some specific properties that do not appear in the discrete star equation. To that purpose, we de- fine a L ́vy multiplicative chaos that generalizes the already existing constructions. (Joint work with R.Rhodes and V.Vargas)
